val:
Sporting Group

Naturally active and alert, Sporting Dogs make likable and well-rounded companions.

Typically pointers and setters would identify and mark game by pointing, spaniels would flush the game out, and retrievers would be in charge of recovering dead and wounded game.

Known for their superior instincts in water and woods, many of these breeds enjoy hunting and other field activities.

Many of them, especially the water-retrieving breeds, have well insulated and water repellant coats, which makes these breads quite resilient to the elements.

There are four basic types of Sporting Dogs:

  • Spaniels
  • Pointers
  • Retrievers
  • Setters

Spaniels

In assisting hunters, Spaniels work within gun range, are steady to shots, able to mark the fall and retrieve shot game with a soft mouth.

A good nose is highly valued, as it is in most gun dog breeds.

They are versatile hunters and whether hunting in open fields, woodlands, farmlands, in briars, along fencerows or marshlands, a spaniel can get the job done.

  • Blue Picardy Spaniel

  • Russian Spaniel

Pointers

These dogs are trained for field reconnaissance.

The moment they sense the prey they freeze in the position they caught the prey’s smell and remain like a statue with a lifted paw and the snout pointing in the direction of the prey.

They freeze in this position until released by the hunter.

They are big sized dogs, with expressive eyes, big and floppy ears, a very good sense of smell and with a special passion for searching the prey.

The Pointers are active through their character, submissive, loyal, and gentle.

Having a pretty powerful hunter instinct, they are not trustful around small animals, including cats.

Many from these dogs were raised to work far away from the hunter and could have independent thinking, and have the tendency to roam.

Pointer Breeds

  • Brittany
  • French Brittany
  • English Pointer
  • German Shorthaired Pointer
  • German Wirehaired Pointer
  • German Longhaired Pointer
  • German Roughhaired Pointer
  • Italian Spinone
  • Pudelpointer
  • Small Munsterlander
  • Large Munsterlander
  • Old Danish Pointer
  • Vizsla
  • Wirehaired Viszla
  • Weimaraner
  • Wirehaired Pointing Griffon
  • Burgos Pointer
  • Portuguese Pointer
  • Slovakian Wirehaired Pointer
  • Cesky Fousek
  • Arrange Pointer

Retrievers

Retrievers are originally hunting dogs whose job was to collect the kill.

That is, the different breeds of this type of dog were bred and trained to collect the game and bring it back to the hunter.

The retriever’s willingness to please, patient nature and trainability have made breeds such as the Labrador Retriever and Golden Retriever popular as a disability assistance dog.

Retriever Breeds

  • Chesapeake Bay Retriever
  • Curly Coated Retriever
  • Flat-Coated Retriever
  • Golden Retriever
  • Labrador Retriever
  • Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever

Setters

A Setter silently searches for game by scent. When prey is encountered the Setter freezes rather than chasing after the game.

Setters get their name from their distinctive stance: a sort of crouch or “set” upon finding their quarry.

Setter tend to be happy, playful dogs and are usually very friendly both to people and other dogs.

They have a great deal of energy and require daily exercise.

Setter Breeds

  • English Setter
  • Gordon Setter
  • Irish Red Setter
  • Irish Red and White Setter
  • Llewellin Setter

Working Group

Dogs that are categorized into the Working Group have historically been responsible for tasks ranging from pulling sleds and carts to guarding flocks and homes.

These dogs include farm and draft animals, security, police, and military dogs, as well as guide and service dogs.

As such, they make dependable, loyal pets with incredible intelligence and energy.

Without the right training, some working dogs can be difficult to handle, even dangerous, some working dog breeds may not be for the first-time dog owner.

There are over 50 dogs in this group, so I mention here the most popular ones.

Toy Group

The toy breed was bred for the purpose of serving as companions for their humans.

These small, easily portable dogs can be most often found sitting in the lap of their humans or being carried around, have been bred down from their larger cousins.

Ideal for anyone with limited space, these little fellas are intelligent, sociable, and full of energy, and despite their small stature, many do have strong protective instincts and big personalities.

There are over 20 dogs in this group, so I mention here the most popular ones.

Toy Group Breeds

  • Silky Terrier
  • English Toy Spaniel
  • Yorkshire Terrier
  • Affenpinscher
  • Toy Poodle
  • Beaglier
  • Bolognese Dog
  • Biewer Terrier
  • Russian Tsvetnaya Bolonka
  • Toy Manchester Terrier

Herding Group

This group includes 30 breeds in a wide variety of sizes, from the Corgi to the German Shepherd with the most straightforward task. Herding dogs have historically been bred to gather, herd, and protect livestock, and work closely with human shepherds. Today, some like the Belgian Malinois and the German Shepherd Dog are commonly used for police, military and protection work. Herding Dogs are highly intelligent and trainable, with a huge desire to please their loved ones.

Hound Group

The Hound Dogs are dogs that have specifically been bred to pursue a warm-blooded game.

This group encompasses a diverse array of breeds.

Generally, the charming, affectionate dogs in this group will make loyal companions and family pets.

Some will require more vigorous exercise than others and more intense training than some.

There are three types of hound, with several breeds within each type:

  • Sight Hounds
  • Scent Hounds
  • Miscellaneous Hounds

Sight Hounds

Sight Hounds Sleek, long-legged sighthounds rely on their explosive speed, incredible stamina, and sharp, wide vision to chase fast animals like jackrabbits and antelope and either bring them down or hold them at bay until the hunter arrives.

  • Schottish Deerhound

Scent Hounds

Scent hounds are responsible for using their acute sense of smell to track game and are known for being more rugged and durable and having the ability to trail just about anything—whether it’s a squirrel or a missing person.

Miscellaneous Hounds

A number of breeds do not hunt solely by speed, sight, and scent, pursuing their prey using both sight and scent.

These breeds are difficult to classify, as they are neither sighthounds nor scenthounds.

Miscellaneous Hound Breeds

  • Cirneco dell’ Etna
  • Podenco Ibicenco
  • Pharaoh Hound
  • Portuguese Podengo
  • Rhodesian Ridgeback
  • Peruvian Inca Orchid
  • Thai Ridgeback

Terrier Group

Terrier is a type of dog originally created to hunt earthy animals: rats, moles, badgers.

Terrier breeds vary greatly in size and form, but there’s one thing which is common to all is their feisty, mischievous personality and energetic nature.

Even small terriers take the “I’m in charge” attitude which can be a problem if they’re not socialized and trained.

They will challenge much bigger dogs, so you must be on your toes when around other dogs.

Bull Terrier breeds were once created for bull baiting and dogfights, but, happily, they are now some of today’s companion dogs.

Non-Sporting Group

The only thing the dogs in the non-sporting group have in common is that they don’t have enough in common with the breeds of any other group.

The Non-Sporting Dogs are all the dogs that remain. They vary greatly in size, function, and history.

Most of these dogs make generally good house dogs and watchdogs, but with breeds ranging from the French Bulldog to the Poodle, their differences are so vast that it makes it difficult to generalize their individual traits.

  • Bulldog

Knowledge Makes You and Your Dog Happy! Furry Canine Team
